clinical_study.brief_title: Standard Versus Mnemonic Counseling for Fecal Incontinence
clinical_study.official_title: Standard Versus Mnemonic Counseling for Fecal Incontinence: a Pilot Randomised Control Trial

oversight_info.authority: United States: Clinical and Translational Sciences Center University of New Mexico

brief_summary.textblock: This study compares standard versus mnemonic counseling for the treatment of fecal incontinence. A mnemonic is a word or rhyme used to aid memory. Our hypothesis is that women randomised to mnemonic counseling will higher recall of treatments, satisfaction with the physician visit and greater improvement in their quality of life when compared to women who received standard counseling.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Single Blind (Outcomes Assessor), Primary Purpose: Treatment

primary_outcome.time_frame: We are measuring the difference in recall the day of the physician counseling and 2 months after physician counselling
primary_outcome.description: Patients will be asked to recall treatments recommended for fecal incontinence.

secondary_outcome.measure: Questionare on the Quality of the Physician and Patient Interaction
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Patients will complete this questionnaire following the physician counseling on day 1 of enrollment.
We are comparing the score change from after the physician counselling on day 1 of enrollment and at 2 month follow-up.

arm_group.description: Patients in this arm are randomised to standard counselling.
Patients in this arm are randomised to counselling with the aid of a mnemonic.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Over 18 years of age
- Diagnosed with fecal incontinence by on of the attending physicians
- Bothersome fecal incontinence symptoms for at least 3 months
- Able to give informed consent
- Able to speak, read and comprehend English
Exclusion Criteria:
- Younger than 18 years
- Fecal Incontinence <3 months
- Unable to give informed consent
- Unable to speak, read and comprehend English
- Diagnosis of active colorectal or anal malignancy, inflammatory bowel disease, recto-vaginal fistula, and rectal prolapse
